block.p: Amazon Reports a Loss That Is Less Than Expected Amazon.com posted third-quarter results that beat Wall Street's expectations, reporting higher sales and a narrower loss than analysts had forecast.

Excluding the cost of stock options, noncash charges and losses from its investments, Amazon lost $68 million, or 25 cents a share, well below the 33 cents analysts had forecast. The company's sales rose 79 percent, to $638 million from $355.8 million. Shares of Amazon, which closed down 44.25 cents, at $29.56, rose to $33.31 in after-hours trading. [Page C2.]

Compaq Results Exceed Forecasts Compaq Computer reported earnings and sales figures that topped Wall Street's expectations, bolstering arguments that the company is rebounding from problems that had hurt its performance over the last two years. Before Compaq announced its results, its shares rose 70 cents, to $28.40. [C7.]

Dow Increases, but Nasdaq Slips Blue-chip stocks rose but high-technology stocks slumped. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 121.35 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,393.07. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.35 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,398.13, but the Nasdaq composite index fell 48.90 points, or 1.4 percent, to 3,419.79. [C12.]

Approval Is Sought for Genetic Corn Even as it struggles to remove an unauthorized variety of genetically engineered corn from the nation's food chain, the developer of that corn, Aventis CropScience, is preparing to ask the government for temporary authorization for the corn to be used in food, according to food industry and government officials. [C6.]

Drugmakers Post Solid Earnings Pfizer posted a 30 percent gain in third-quarter profit, exceeding Wall Street expectations, while net income at Schering-Plough rose 14 percent, matching expectations. [C4.]

Online Sports Retailer to Be Sold Fogdog, an online sporting goods retailer, agreed to be acquired by Global Sports, which provides e-commerce services to retailers, for $38.4 million in Global Sports stock, the companies said. [C6.]

His Mistakes Are Shown on ESPN Larry Young, left, who has been a Major League umpire for 18 years, says he found out early that it's easy to throw a person out of the game. ''You can do that every night. It's hard to keep someone in the game. Look at Roger Clemens the other night. Charlie Reliford, the umpire, got in between Mike Piazza and Clemens and defused the situation. Reliford could have thrown him out. But the players have more respect for you if you go in and try to use some psychology.'' The Boss. [C8.]

Ford Demonstrates New Devices Seeking to restore its reputation for safety and respond to high gasoline prices, Ford announced high-technology approaches to improving traffic safety and gas mileage. Among the devices demonstrated were tiny cameras that will send images from all around a vehicle to the dashboard as well as bumper-mounted air bags for the protection of pedestrians. [C4.]

Nasdaq Japan Sells a 15% Stake Nasdaq Japan, the fledgling stock market that is a joint venture of the National Association of Securities Dealers and Softbank, has sold a 15 percent stake to a group of foreign and domestic brokers. [World Business, Section W.]
Oil Companies Post Record Profits Exxon Mobil, Chevron and Texaco all posted record third-quarter earnings as oil prices reached nine-year highs. All three companies beat Wall Street estimates. [C2.]

Banks to Fight Money Laundering A group of major international banks, stung by the growing reputation of the banking industry as a haven for ill-gotten gains, plans to form a global front against money laundering. [World Business, Section W.]
